tossups.question: A cow-herder named Dorcon puts on the skin of one of these animals to surprise Chloe, but is attacked by Chloe’s dogs. The son of Pelasgus and Meliboea was transformed into one of these animals as punishment for murdering his son Nyctimus. During a holiday named for these animals, any woman hit with a whip made from a sacrificed animal was supposedly made fertile. The Arcadian king (*) Lycaon was transformed into one of these animals, which are the namesakes of a Roman festival that may be the origin of Valentine’s Day. A female one of these animals suckled the twin founders of Rome, Romulus and Remus. For 10 points, name these animals, one of whom disguises itself as the grandmother of Little Red Riding Hood.
tossups.answer: wolves [or wolf; accept she-wolf]

tossups.question: Amateur historian Fritz Tobias’s research into this event attacked the long-popular claims in Willi Munzenberg’s Brown Book, which blamed this event on Edmund Heines. A judge dismissed charges related to this event brought against three Bulgarians, including the first postwar leader of Bulgaria, Georgi Dimitrov. Legislation commonly named for this event suspended the right of free assembly that had been guaranteed by a (*) 1919 constitution. A Dutch communist named Marinus van der Lubbe was responsible for this event, although it’s possible it was a false flag operation by Hermann Göring. The Nazis consolidated powerafter, for 10 points, what 1933 event in which the German parliament building was set ablaze?
tossups.answer: Reichstag Fire [or Reichstagsbrand]

tossups.question: A character created by this author frets that she receives a dinner invitation on plain-white rather than “pigeon-blood notepaper” while staying in the Stentorian Hotel. In a novel by this author, that native of Apex drives her second husband Ralph Marvell to suicide. The main characters of another novel by this author are first observed through the opera glasses of Lawrence Lefferts. In that novel by this creator of Undine Spragg, one of the two main characters had just divorced a (*) Polish nobleman and returned to New York. That novel by this author ends with the protagonist in Paris, declining an opportunity to visit Ellen Olenska. For 10 points, Newland Archer was created by what author of The Custom of the Country and The Age of Innocence?
tossups.answer: Edith Wharton [or Edith Newbold Jones]

tossups.question: Eukaryotic exocytosis is classified based on whether it is or isn’t dependent on this ion. Intracellular levels of this ion are increased by the cleavage of PIP2 (“pip-two”) into DAG and IP3 when IP3 binds to its receptor. Blood pressure drugs like dihydropyridines block channels for this ion. The acrosome reaction causes an influx of this ion into oocytes. Depolarization of the (*) T-tubules leads to the release of this ion into the cytoplasm by receptors in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. This ion binds to troponin, causing a conformational change that exposes myosin-binding sites to actin. Osteoclast activity increases in response to low blood levels of this ion. For 10 points, name this cation (“CAT-eye-on”) that aids in muscle contraction and is stored in bones.
tossups.answer: calcium [or Ca2+]

tossups.question: This character, who is twice compared to a bull before being introduced, brags of having “mastered all the arts of cowardice” and gives a speech noting that “even Greeks look down on other Greeks, too clever to see the good in them.” A nurse warns that those who attract the hatred of this character should not expect “to go home singing.” This character uses a chariot decorated with dragon wings to visit a mountain sacred to (*) Hera before traveling to exile in Athens at the court of King Aegeus. This barbarian granddaughter of Helios creates a poison garment that kills King Creon after being angered by her husband marrying Glauce (“glossy”). For 10 points, name this title character of a Euripides drama who murders her children to get revenge on Jason.
tossups.answer: Medea [or Mēdeia]

tossups.question: In a Woody Allen film, Paul contradicts a tour guide’s description of this artist’s life, much to the annoyance of Gil Pender. This sculptor disowned a student who created a work depicting drapes swirling around a "Vanished God" and Clotho. That work, by a student of this artist, is The Mature Age. This mentor of (*) Camille Claudel sculpted a writer with an enormous neck draped in a dressing gown. This sculptor of a Monument to Balzac also crafted six bronze figures with nooses around their necks for a work set during the Hundred Years’ War. The Burghers of Calais was created by, for 10 points, what sculptor who included The Thinker in his Gates of Hell?
tossups.answer: Auguste Rodin

tossups.question: Edward Corsi oversaw a 1953 relief law named for this general class of people that granted exceptions to the McCarran–Walter Act. In 1930, one organization founded an office named for polar explorer Fridtjof Nansen that focused on these people. The 1996 case of Chahal v. UK reinforced the non-refoulement (“non-ruh-FOOL-mont”) rights of these people. Today, many of this general class of people live in Bidibidi in Uganda. It’s not a specific ethnic group, but Jimmy Carter signed a 1980 law named for these people that benefited so-called (*) “boat people.” The UNHCR supports these people, whom the UN defines as having “a well-founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race or religion.” For 10 points, name these people forced to cross national borders.
tossups.answer: refugees [or migrants; or economic migrants; or stateless refugees; or asylum seekers; accept refugee camps; or stateless people; accept IDP or internally displaced persons]

tossups.question: Factories producing this metal account for 90 percent of emissions of the greenhouse gas tetrafluoromethane. For nearly two hundred years, Greenland supplied the world with this metal’s fluoride, which was used to dissolve its other ores. The FAA states that only government employees can carry barometers on planes due to mercury’s rapid amalgamation with this metal. The American Chemical Society differs from IUPAC on how to (*) refer to this metal. An electrolytic method of smelting this metal was patented in the US and France nearly simultaneously. This Group 13 metal makes up one-twelfth of the Earth's crust by weight, but must be refined from bauxite via the Hall–Héroult (“ay-ROO”) process. For 10 points, name this lightweight silvery metal used in soda cans.
tossups.answer: aluminum [or Al; or aluminium]

tossups.question: In this symphony’s second movement, Michael Kennedy noted that he heard parts of the abandoned scherzo “Christmas games with the child.” The trombones and trumpets play a marching theme based on the recurring motif (read slowly) E-flat, low B-flat, up to A-flat in this symphony’s first movement. The entire chorus sings “Accende lumen sensibus” in the first “surge in E major” in this symphony, whose closing “Chorus (*) Mysticus” chorale sets a passage that praises the “Eternal Feminine.” Its second and final movement sets text from Goethe’s (“GUR-tuh’s”) Faust, while the first is a setting of Veni, creator spiritus. Vocal soloists were joined by a hundred-plus member orchestra and three choirs at the Munich premiere of, for 10 points, what Gustav Mahler symphony?
tossups.answer: Symphony of a Thousand [or Gustav Mahler’s Symphony No. 8 in E-flat major; accept 8th after “Mahler” is read]

tossups.question: These events are represented by an equilibrium point more to the left than an LRAS curve on an AD–AS (“A-D-A-S”) diagram. In the US, these events are officially demarcated by the NBER (“N-burr”) and have historically been preceded by an inverted yield curve for US Treasury bonds. RBC theory holds that these events are largely caused by adverse productivity shocks. These events can begin particularly long-lasting periods that are said to be (*) L-shaped. A “double-dip” example of one of these events was caused by Paul Volcker raising interest rates in the 1980s. In classic business cycle theory, these events are contrasted with expansions. For 10 points, name these periods of declining aggregate economic activity.
tossups.answer: economic recessions [or economic depressions; or contractions; or corrections; prompt on stock-market crashes]

tossups.question: Advanced versions of these systems often employ the OpenADR standard. Harvard economist Bill Hogan helped design one of these systems managed by ERCOT rather than federal regulators. In 2013, one of these systems in California was badly damaged in the Metcalf sniper attack. The EU is funding a new one of these systems in the Baltic to align with the Continental Synchronous Area as a defense mechanism against Russian (*) cyberattacks. California’s deregulation of this system led to the recall of Gray Davis and market opportunities for Enron. In February 2021, an isolated system of this type called the Texas Interconnection failed during an unusual cold spout. For 10 points, name these utility systems that include transmission lines and generators.
tossups.answer: electrical grid [or power grid; or energy management systems; prompt on grid or smart grid; anti-prompt on demand response systems or power plants or reactors]

tossups.question: In the far-field regime, the intensity profile of these things is given by the square of the sinc (“sink”) function. Babinet’s principle states that for complementary objects, these things are opposite in phase, but equal in amplitude. The Fourier transform of the aperture is used to predict the form of these things. High-intensity regions at the center of these things called (*) Airy disks are used to define the Rayleigh criterion. Minimum intensity bands in these things occur where the slit width times the sine of the incidence angle equals an integer multiple of wavelength. Constructive and destructive interference cause the light and dark bands seen in these things. For 10 points, what images are seen downstream of where a light wave bends through a hole?
tossups.answer: diffraction patterns [accept interference patterns until “interference” is read; accept diffraction fringes; prompt on fringes or patterns by asking “what phenomenon is forming them?”; prompt on images until read]

tossups.question: A priest in this novel declares, “The tragedy is not that things are broken. The tragedy is that things are not mended again.” The title phrase of this novel precedes a passage lamenting “the unborn child that’s inheritor of our fear.” This book’s first chapter warns “Destroy it and man is destroyed” when praising the beautiful land near a “lovely road that runs” through the hills. The protagonist addresses (*) Tixo (“tee-ko”), or God, several times in this novel, and is himself called umfundisi (“oom-foon-DEE-see”). Many oft-quoted lines from this novel are uttered by the priest Theophilus Msimangu (“thee-OFF-uh-luss mm-see-MAHN-goo”). The plot of this novel is set into motion by Absalom’s murder of Arthur Jarvis. For 10 points, Stephen Kumalo’s son is tried for murder in Johannesburg in what Alan Paton (“PAY-ton”) novel?
tossups.answer: Cry, the Beloved Country

tossups.question: A sharp-pointed one of these devices called a kuan was in wide use by the time of China’s Qin (“chin”) dynasty. Historian Lynn White argued that the replacement of Roman “scratch” varieties of these devices with heavy moldboard variants led to increased population densities in Northern Europe in the Middle Ages. In the 19th century, homesteaders wrongly believed a theory that rain “followed” from using these devices. Over-use of these devices can result in (*) hardpan, which prevents proper drainage. An all-steel version of this technology that slid well through the thick terrain of the Great Plains was developed by John Deere. For 10 points, name this farming device typically attached to a tractor to break up and churn soil.
tossups.answer: plow [or steam plow; or plough; accept ard; accept scratch plough or moldboard plough; prompt on tractors]

tossups.question: A smokestack and an iron bridge appear in a view of this city titled Morning, An Overcast Day, which is part of a series that Camille Pissarro painted here in 1896. Another artist justified his paintings made in this city with the quote, “Everything changes, even stone.” All but two of the paintings made by that same artist in this city were done at an oblique angle from a rented studio above Fernand Lévy’s boutique. Those paintings were finished at a studio in (*) Giverny (“zhee-vair-NEE”). The portal of a Gothic building in this city was shown under conditions of sunset and “red sunlight” by an artist also known for his Haystacks. For 10 points, name this French city whose cathedral was repeatedly painted by Claude Monet.
tossups.answer: Rouen (“roo-AWN”) [or Rouen, France]

tossups.question: During a 1986 senate run, this politician was criticized for his ties to “Duke” Tully, a reporter who had pretended to be a veteran. David Foster Wallace’s reporting on this politician for Rolling Stone was published into a book titled for this man’s campaign bus. Voters were asked if they would vote for this man if he “had fathered an illegitimate Black child” in robocalls engineered by (*) Karl Rove. In his most successful presidential run, this politician made repeated appearances with a business owner nicknamed “Joe the Plumber.” This man and Russ Feingold created a 2002 act that reformed campaign financing. For 10 points, name this Arizona Senator defeated by Barack Obama in the 2008 election.
tossups.answer: John McCain [or John Sidney McCain III]

tossups.question: One story by this author ends with the title character declaring, “For the future let those who come to play with me have no hearts” after a “funny little Dwarf” dies. The title statue of another story by this author asks a swallow to give away his gemstones to poor townspeople before both of them die. In a novel by this author of “The Birthday of the Infanta,” the protagonist is known only by the name Prince Charming to an (*) actress who commits suicide after giving a stilted performance. This author of “The Happy Prince” wrote a novel that opens with Basil Hallward trying to prevent Lord Henry Wotton from meeting the protagonist while painting the title object. For 10 points, name this author of The Picture of Dorian Gray.
tossups.answer: Oscar Wilde [or Oscar Fingal O’Flahertie Wills Wilde]

tossups.question: A man named Bolor Minjin has led the effort to repatriate these items, many of which come from an area called the Flaming Cliffs. The Ruth Hall Museum exhibits two collections of these items from Georgia O’Keeffe’s Ghost Ranch. A Gilded Age “war” over these items was partially fought by Othniel Charles Marsh. The luxury market for these items was kicked off by the 1997 auction of one nicknamed (*) “Sue.” UNESCO recognizes the Gobi Desert in Mongolia as the world’s largest “reservoir” of these items. Some of these things are called coprolites, and many are collected in a “hall” named for David H. Kock at the National Museum of Natural History. For 10 points, name these items sought by paleontologists, which might include the skull of a T-rex.
tossups.answer: dinosaur bones [or dinosaur fossils; or dinosaur eggs; or dinosaur skeleton; prompt on ancient bones or remains; prompt on animal bones or remains; prompt on eggs; prompt on dinosaurs]

tossups.question: A “great wrath” comes against Israel after Mesha, king of Moab, performs this action during a losing battle in chapter 3 of Second Kings. In another biblical book, someone chosen to undergo this action is described by four increasingly-specific phrases, including “your only one” and “whom you love.” When the judge Jephthah asks God to deliver the Ammonites into his hand, he accidentally (*) promises God that he will perform this action. God promises to “greatly multiply your seed, as the stars in the heavens and as the sand on the shores of the sea” when a man substitutes a ram for an intended victim of this action. For 10 points, what intended action by Abraham involved going to Moriah and binding his son Isaac on an altar?
tossups.answer: human sacrifice [or child sacrifice; accept offering; accept burnt sacrifice; accept descriptions of specific events like Abraham sacrificing Isaac or binding of Isaac; prompt on killing, murdering, burning, slaughtering, or other similar answers indicating killing]

tossups.question: Manfred Eigen’s Nobel lecture describes measuring “immeasurably” large values of this quantity by observing the relaxation of a system after inducing a jump in conditions. Three values of this quantity for the transient ES (“E-S”) complex are combined to form the specificity constant, which never exceeds the order of ten-to-the-ninth because it is limited by diffusion. In the quasi-steady-state, the forward and reverse values of this quantity are equal, which is a major assumption of (*) Michaelis–Menten theory. This quantity is proportional to concentration raised to the order times a namesake constant. For 10 points, name this quantity that is increased by catalysts and that measures how quickly products of a reaction are formed.
tossups.answer: reaction rate [accept rate constant; accept reaction velocity]

tossups.question: For some of his homes, this architect buried heating pipes in slabs of concrete to create “holocaust heating,” better known as radiant heating. Despite the original contractor’s use of extra reinforcement, high-tension steel cables needed to be used in a 2002 restoration of sagging balconies designed by this man. His longtime mistress was killed when Julian Carlton burned down this man’s own home, prompting him to build a new (*) “West” version of it with “desert masonry” in Scottsdale. This man coined the term “carport” while designing his many Usonian Homes. Edgar Kaufmann hired this man to design a house whose cantilevered edges extend out over a Bear Run waterfall. For 10 points, name this architect of Taliesin and Fallingwater.
tossups.answer: Frank Lloyd Wright

bonuses.leadin: A man in this state of being contemplates a thistle plant in a lengthy modernist poem by Hugh MacDiarmid (“mac-DUR-mid”). For 10 points each:
answers: drunken [accept equivalents such as intoxicated or inebriated; accept A Drunk Man Looks at the Thistle]
Scotland [prompt on U.K. or United Kingdom]
parts: Give this state of being. A character who is often in this state of being names a style of men’s bonnet and exclaims “Well done, Cutty-sark!” upon seeing some witches dance at a sabbath.
The author of “Tam o’ Shanter” also wrote this poem that is often set to music and used as a drinking song. It asks “should old acquaintance be forgot, and never brought to mind?”
“Tam o’ Shanter” and “Auld Lang Syne” were written in the language of this country by its national poet, Robert Burns.

bonuses.leadin: Deep inelastic scattering provided evidence of these particles. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these particles whose six flavors have charges equal to two-thirds and negative-one-third of the elementary charge.

A quark and antiquark form these particles, which are both the lightest mesons and lightest hadrons. The Hagedorn (“HA-guh-dorn”) temperature at which matter is believed to evaporate or convert into quark matter equals the mass-energy of these particles.

This hypothetical exotic meson is predicted by the standard model to have a total angular momentum of either 2 or 3 in the ground state. These hard-to-validate particles are formed entirely of the carrier of the strong force.

bonuses.leadin: In the Kongo kingdom, high-quality goods of this type were frequently used as currency. For 10 points each:
answers: cloth [or textiles; or fabrics; or clothing; prompt on cotton or flax]
seashells [or sea snail shells; or shell money; or cowrie shells]
parts: Identify this type of good. Other African examples of this type of good include the kente variety made by the Akan people.
Another medium of exchange in the Kongo kingdom was the nzimbu, a type of these objects. The Portuguese flooded the market for these items by importing them in bulk from the Indian Ocean.
The Akan people also made brass figurines to measure precise amounts of this precious metal. The massive Holtermann Nugget was found during a mania for this metal in Australia in the 1850s.

bonuses.leadin: This book advances a form of occasionalism according to which, when cotton is set on fire, it is really God that burns the cotton. For 10 points each:
answers: The Incoherence of the Philosophers [or Tahafut al-Falasifah] (by al-Ghazali)
Thomas Aquinas [or Tomasso d’Aquino; prompt on Saint Thomas]
parts: Name this relentless attack on Avicenna’s philosophy which argues that several doctrines derived from Aristotle and Plato amount to “unbelief” in Islam.

Avicenna legendarily read this Aristotle text forty times without understanding it until he read al-Farabi’s commentary. This book on “first philosophy” delineates material, formal, efficient, and final causes.
Averroes (“ah-VAIR-oh-eez”) is cited for his commentaries on the Metaphysics in the Summa Theologica, which is by this medieval scholastic philosopher.

bonuses.leadin: The heavy demand for these singers during the 17th and 18th centuries made stars out of Senesino (“say-nay-ZEE-no”) and Farinelli. For 10 points each:
answers: castrati [or castrato; accept castrated singers or equivalents; prompt on eunuchs or countertenors]
C6 (“C-six”) [accept informal terms such as soprano C or high C; do not accept anything that is explicitly not C6, such as “C5”]
parts: Name these male opera singers who could hit high notes because doctors removed their genitals before they hit puberty.

Farinelli could hit this highest note that sopranos were asked to sing at the time. Since then, soprano arias have occasionally ventured higher, such as with the high Fs in Mozart’s “Der Hölle Rache (“dair HUR-luh RAH-khuh”).”
This composer used female travesti roles for Tancredi to imitate the sound of castrati. One of his comic operas features the iconic aria “Largo al factotum.”

bonuses.leadin: Ahmad ibn Hanbal was flogged on the orders of the Abbasid caliph al-Mu‘tasim because of his position in this religious debate. For 10 points each:
answers: whether or not the Qur’an is created [or whether or not the Qur’an is eternal; or whether or not the Qur’an is pre-existent; accept any answer mentioning the words created or uncreated or eternal or pre-exist but do not accept any answer that does not use one of these words]
parts: Name this debate about the Qur’an, for which al-Ma’mun organized the Mihna as an inquisition to enforce the teachings of the rationalistic Mu‘tazilites. A descriptive answer is necessary.
The name of this branch of Islam comes from the body of Muhammad’s practices. Members of this largest branch of Islam reject the createdness of the Qur’an, unlike most Shia.
Ibn Hanbal founded one of the four Sunni madhhabs (“math-HABS”), or schools of thought in this field of Islamic jurisprudence that interprets the meaning of Sharia law.

bonuses.leadin: This algorithm outputs an E-value that decreases exponentially as the number of matches increases. For 10 points each:
answers: BLAST [or Basic Local Alignment Search Tool]
homologous [accept homology or homologous sequences or homologous structures]
parts: Name this algorithm used for sequence alignment of DNA and proteins. This algorithm uses FASTA files as input and is run by the NCBI.

BLAST can be used to assess whether or not two sequences have this quality. The pentadactyl limb found in humans and other vertebrates has this quality, which means that it was derived from a shared common ancestor.
The existence of homologous structures implies that this type of evolution has occurred. This type of evolution leads to speciation.

bonuses.leadin: One version of this text found in modern-day Susa, Iran, was written on a stele (“STEE-lee”) with an image of Shamash giving its namesake a rod and a ring. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this ancient law code promulgated by a king of the First Babylonian dynasty.

The text in the Stele of the Code of Hammurabi is written in this language, also known as Assyro-Babylonian. Since 1921, the University of Chicago has published a dictionary of this East Semitic language.

Fragments of Hammurabi’s Code have been found in this city, whose “scribal corner” is rich with ancient texts. Various Mesopotamian dynasties sought to control this city of religious importance, the home of the god Enlil.

bonuses.leadin: In a self-portrait, the wings of a dead one of these animals echo the subject’s thick eyebrows. For 10 points each:
answers: Frida Kahlo [or Magdalena Carmen Frida Kahlo y Calderón]
column [or Ionic column; or The Broken Column; or La Columna Rota; or pillar]
parts: Identify this animal that hangs from a thorn necklace in a self-portrait that also depicts a monkey, cat, and butterfly.
Self-Portrait with Thorn Necklace and Hummingbird is a painting by this Mexican artist who often depicted herself with a unibrow.
Another Kahlo self-portrait allegorizes her chronic pain from a bus accident by replacing her spine with a broken one of these objects.

bonuses.leadin: The speaker of a poem who has just finished with this activity “cannot rub the strangeness from my sight / I got from looking through a pane of glass.” For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this title activity that causes the speaker to dream a dream where “the ladder sways as the boughs (“bows”) bend.”
“After Apple Picking” is a poem by this author of the collection North of Boston who wrote “Mending Wall.”
The narrator of this Robert Frost poem envisions the title trees as having been bent “to left and right” because “some boy’s been swinging them.”

bonuses.leadin: NASA won an Emmy Award for documenting the end of this space probe’s life in 2017. For 10 points each:
answers: Cassini-Huygens [or ASI/NASA Cassini orbiter; or Cassini probe]
rings of Saturn [or Saturn’s rings; prompt on rings]
Roche limit [or Roche radius; do not accept or prompt on “Roche lobe”]
parts: Name this probe that was “de-orbited” to avoid contaminating any water-bearing moons. This probe’s inclined orbits allowed a final look at a distinct polar feature during its Grand Finale.

Debate over the age of these objects was fueled by data gathered as the Grand Finale passed between them and their parent planet. The Cassini probe shares its namesake with a division between the A and B examples of these objects.
Saturn’s rings were formed from moons that were torn apart because they lay inside this boundary, inside which satellites are destroyed by tidal forces.

bonuses.leadin: The president of this country, José Figueres (“fee-GAY-ress”), once took a sledgehammer to its military headquarters, the Cuartel Bellavista. For 10 points each:
answers: Costa Rica [or Republic of Costa Rica]
parts: Identify this Latin American country that abolished its military in 1948.

Costa Rica absorbed many refugees from this other Central American country during the Sandinista war. The Iran-Contra affair involved the US government selling weapons to rebels in this country, whose capital is Managua.

This man reinstated slavery during his brief rule of Nicaragua starting in 1856. During his rule, he gave control of Accessory Transit Company assets to C. K. Garrison and Charles Morgan, attracting the ire of Cornelius Vanderbilt.

bonuses.leadin: One of the contributions Imhotep made to Egyptian civilization is mythologically attributed to the god Thoth. For 10 points each:
answers: Ra [or Re or Amun or Atum or combinations thereof]
parts: In the myth, Thoth allowed the sky goddess to give birth by winning at dice against Khonsu, who repeatedly wagered this substance.
This sky goddess, the wife of Geb, gave birth to one child on each of the extra days won by Thoth. The first child this goddess gave birth to was the fertility god Osiris.
The extra days were needed because this sun god had forbidden Nut from bearing children during any month of the year.

bonuses.leadin: Observations satisfying these assumptions are exchangeable, so their order can be perturbed without affecting the joint probability. For 10 points each:
answers: independent AND identically distributed [or i.i.d.; prompt on partial answer; prompt on uncorrelated]
expected value [or expectation; or EV; prompt on E; prompt on average or arithmetic mean; do not accept or prompt on “mean”]
normal distribution [accept Gaussian distribution or Laplace–Gauss distribution]
parts: Name these frequently paired assumptions that are violated by time series. Sufficiently long sequences of variables obeying these two assumptions have the characteristic function e to the negative one-half t-squared.

The law of large numbers states that the mean of i.i.d. variables converges to this value. In the continuous case, this value is the integral over the range of x times the probability density function of x.
The central limit theorem predicts that a sample mean of i.i.d. variables will follow this bell-shaped distribution.

bonuses.leadin: A 19th-century novel about a “country” version of this character written by a “fake” version of its author inspired many shunga (“SHOON-gah”) prints. For 10 points each:
answers: fireflies [or lightning bugs; or glow-worms; prompt on insects]
parts: Identify this literary character whose death is implied in the “Vanished into the Clouds” section of a book titled after him.
The Tale of Genji is a literary treasure from this Asian country.
In a chapter of The Tale of Genji titled for these things, Genji releases these things to allow Prince Hotaru to see the face of the young woman Tamakazura, who has been rejecting Genji’s advances.

bonuses.leadin: This battle allegedly began after Confederate soldiers went into the namesake town to look for shoes. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this northernmost major battle of the Civil War. It ended after Pickett’s Charge led to heavy Confederate casualties on July 3rd, 1863.
On the second day of the battle, Confederate troops under James Longstreet attempted to flank the Union army by attacking this hill on the end of Cemetery Ridge.

This Union Colonel received a Medal of Honor for his leadership of the 20th Maine infantry at Little Round Top. After his troops ran out of bullets, he ordered a bayonet charge that broke Confederate lines.

bonuses.leadin: A group of composers from this country was derisively called the Cow Pat School. For 10 points each:
answers: United Kingdom [or UK; or England; or Great Britain; or Scotland]
Ralph Vaughan Williams (“rayf von williams”) [prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this country whose folk music scene was revived by Australian-born composer Percy Grainger with arrangements of Morris dancing songs like “Country Gardens.”
Richard King’s chronicle of English pastoral music, The Lark Ascending, takes its title from a piece by this composer of Sinfonia antarctica.

Richard King traces idyllic English music from Vaughan Williams to this annual festival held in Somerset. The psychedelic folk act “T. Rex” played at the first iteration of this event, when it was then called the Pilton Pop, Blues & Folk Festival.

bonuses.leadin: A convenience store chain based in this state widely advertises its immaculately clean restrooms and is called Buc-ee’s (“BUCK-eez”). For 10 points each:
answers: Palm Beach County [do not accept or prompt on “West Palm Beach”]
parts: Identify this state where a Buc-ee’s is located at the intersection of I-35 West and SH 114 in Fort Worth.
This state is home to the first United Dairy Farmers convenience store and the first Wendy’s. This state’s capital sits at the confluence of the Olentangy and Scioto (“sy-OH-tuh”) rivers.

Pennsylvania’s Wawa chain has recently branched out to this Florida county, where the Affordable Care Act spawned a bonanza in sober living centers. Boynton Beach is in this county, which is located due north of Broward County.

bonuses.leadin: Ferdinand de Grammont helped the author create coats of arms for the characters in this series, which appear in an armorial published by Fernand Lotte. For 10 points each:
answers: The Human Comedy [or La Comédie humaine]
parts: Name this series whose short stories include “Facino Cane” and “The Unknown Masterpiece.” The title character befriends a panther he nicknames “Mignon” in its story “The Passion in the Desert.”
Balzac championed this literary movement that spawned the later naturalism movement. This movement focused on “the presentation of credible experiences and happenings in literature.”
This philosopher argued that Balzac’s apparent realism was in fact “copying a (depicted) copy of the real.” He examined professional wrestling in an essay in his collection Mythologies.

bonuses.leadin: A grammar of this type is required to encode strings consisting of a number of A’s followed by the same number of B’s followed by the same number of C’s. For 10 points each:
answers: context-sensitive grammar [or context-sensitive language; or CSG; or CSL; do not accept or prompt on “context-free grammar”]
Noam Chomsky [or Avram Noam Chomsky; accept Chomsky hierarchy]
regular [accept regular grammars or regular languages or regular expressions; accept regex]
parts: Give this type of grammar referred to as Type-1 in a hierarchy where Type-0 refers to any recursively-enumerable grammar.
That hierarchy of grammars is named for this MIT linguist who developed the theory of Universal Grammar.

Grammars described by this word are Type-3 in the hierarchy. Grammars described by this word can be modeled with finite state automata as well as by “expressions” described by this word that are used in computer science to match patterns in strings.

bonuses.leadin: Each chapter opens with one of these texts in a novel where Tita’s sister Rosaura dies from excessive flatulence. For 10 points each:
answers: Mexico [or United Mexican States; or UMS; or Estados Unidos Mexicanos]
parts: Identify this genre of the texts which serve as epigraphs for a 1989 novel by Laura Esquivel.

In Like Water for Chocolate, Tita bakes a vomit-inducing cake, but cooks much better food for the wedding of this daughter of Rosaura. A different character with this first name begrudgingly looks after her sister Nenny in The House on Mango Street.
Tita’s family lives in the north of this country. Children and parents leaving this country for one to the north are separated from each other in Valeria Luiselli’s 2019 novel Lost Children Archive.
